awd_titl_txt: Computing with R for Mathematical Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
The depth and complexity of the problems facing the nation and globe increasingly demand complex, computational solutions.  Seeking ways to seamlessly build computational thinking in to high school curricula is one way to prepare students for this future.  Because computer science courses are unavailable in most schools, integrating computational thinking into existing high school courses may be better suited to provide a solution to this gap in students' preparation.  This project will develop a robust infrastructure using the open source statistical program R to support the infusion of computational thinking into high school mathematics courses.  Three online curriculum modules will be developed that integrate computational thinking practices: a) interpreting categorical and quantitative data, b) making inferences and justifying conclusions, and c) linear, quadratic, and exponential models.  The proposed online learning platform will provide wide access to the computing resources, learning resources, and teacher supports.  The project is funded by the STEM+Computing program, which seeks to address emerging challenges in computational STEM areas through the applied integration of computational thinking and computing activities within disciplinary STEM teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school (preK-12).

Linking mathematics to everyday problem solving, mathematical modeling is an iterative cyclic process that involves identifying and selecting variables to represent a situation, choosing mathematical representations to describe the variables and their relationships, performing mathematical operations to draw conclusions, interpreting and validating the conclusions against the situation, and iteratively improving the model.  In the same spirit, computational thinking is the process of formulating problems and solutions in terms of computational steps and algorithms that can be executed by computers.  Both practices aim to connect the real world with the model world, either mathematical or computational, to create solutions to problems.  This project focuses on the coupling of these two strategies.  For example, one focus of the project is an investigation of how variations of coupling strategies impact learning.  This project will systematically manipulate design patterns and compare students' learning outcomes and learning processes across three field tests with Module A.  The steps in a computational mathematical modeling cycle can be grouped into subsets for initial task classes to reduce the complexity of dealing with the entire cycle; however, doing so may decrease the level of authenticity and richness of the tasks. Finding a good balance between engagement and cognitive load control will be the focus of this phase of the study.

CodeR4MATH Outcomes Report

Computational thinking is the process of formulating problems and solutions in terms of computational steps and algorithms that can be executed by an information-processing agent. It is a critical skill that fuels today?s digital economy and enables computational solutions to many grand challenges facing our society. Despite the great demand for computational thinkers, opportunities for students to develop computational thinking skills are scarce at the high school level. Computer sciences classes, which target computational thinking, are typically elective or not offered in many schools. Fortunately, the development of computational thinking skills does not need to be limited to computer sciences classes. In mathematics classes, students learn and practice mathematical modeling, which is an iterative process of using mathematics to represent, analyze, and make predictions for real-world phenomena. This process calls for a variety of computational tools and requires students to think computationally. Therefore, mathematics classrooms present opportunities for students to develop computational thinking skills, especially during the practice of math modeling.

The goal of this project was to develop and research a technology and curricular infrastructure to support the integration of computational thinking into high school mathematics classrooms. The project used the R programming language, a professional-grade yet novice-friendly computing tool, as the primary learning tool. To support student learning, the project curated a collection of R functions and packages suitable for high school classrooms. The project also designed and tested instructional strategies to support students in learning both general programming and R-specific concepts and developing skills to formulate and solve problems using these concepts. To further facilitate learning and teaching in the classroom setting, the project developed two technology platforms: CodeR4MATH and Key2STATS. CodeR4MATH integrates an R code editor and an interactive coding tutoring tool into a curriculum delivery system, providing just-in-time, targeted support to students. Key2STATS also integrates an R code editor into its ecosystem of learning and assessment sources for high school statistics and probability classes, offering students the opportunity to develop computational thinking as they work on learning tasks typically included in these classes.

To fully realize the potential of these two technology platforms, the project also developed, implemented, and refined 11 curriculum modules (7 on CodeR4MATH and 4 on Key2STATS) that support students in developing computational thinking skills. In all modules, students are introduced to the R programming language as a computing tool to solve real-world problems. As students learn and apply programming concepts in math modeling or data exploration tasks, they develop the skills of formulating problems and creating solutions in computational terms, as well as the complementary skills of analyzing, visualizing, and interpreting data.

The project offered professional training to 59 teachers and tested the curriculum modules with a total of 442 students. Project research studied student learning through assessments, questionnaires, classroom observations, interviews, and student work. Analysis of these data sources showed that students without prior experience with coding were engaged in computational thinking, developed fundamental understandings of programming concepts, and formed a computational perspective for math modeling and data analysis. Furthermore, project research investigated teacher professional learning in the domain of computational thinking and computer programming, as well as their perspectives on integrating these content into their math classrooms. Teacher surveys and interviews revealed that participating teachers generally appreciated the value of integrating computational thinking into math learning, but they must consider a number of practical factors and administrative barriers in their school environments.

By developing and researching technology and curriculum in authentic classroom settings, the project established and refined design principles for technology-based learning environments that support secondary students in developing computational thinking skills in the context of math modeling and data analysis. Educators and collaborators involved in the project are applying these design principles in their work to advance computational thinking education.
